key_points: President Donald Trump incited his supporters to fight Congress on accepting the electoral college results showing Joe Biden won.
Trump's call to action resulted in thousands of his supporters storming the Capitol, disrupting the counting of electoral votes.
Before the Jan. 6 riot, Trump hosted the "Save America" rally where his allies, including Rudy Giuliani, made incendiary statements.
Trump's campaign for weeks had spread false claims about the election being rigged and encouraged his supporters to gather in D.C. on Jan. 6.
Several tweets from Trump encouraged his followers to come to Washington D.C. and fight for him leading up to the Capitol assault.
On Jan. 6, Trump repeated false claims of having won the election and directly invited his supporters to march to the Capitol.
Trump only used the word "peacefully" once in his rally speech, amidst several calls to fight.
During the Capitol riot, Trump tweeted support for the Capitol Police and asked for peace but repeated false claims about the election.
Trump's actions before, during, and after the Capitol riot contributed to a violent attempt to overturn the election results.
The investigation of Trump's incitement of the Capitol riot continues, with Trump not responding to inquiries from the press.
